pageContext.claim: “Iran went in, and they hit us with missiles. Shouldn't have done that, but they hit us. Fortunately for them, nobody was hurt, nobody was killed. Nothing happened. They landed -- and very little damage even, to the base.”
pageContext.analysis: Despite Trump's assurances that no soldiers were hurt by the Jan. 8 Iranian missile attack on Ain al-Asad air base in western Iraq, the Pentagon admitted a week later that eleven U.S. troops were injured. Those troops are still being assessed for concussion symptoms following the blast, Navy Capt. Bill Urban, a spokesman for U.S. Central Command, said in a statement on Jan. 16. Eight U.S. troops were evacuated to a U.S. base in Germany, he said, and the other three were sent to Camp Arifjan in Kuwait. At least two soldiers were thrown through the window of a meters-high tower. The Pentagon eventually admitted that 110 U.S. service members were diagnosed with traumatic brain injuries; the eight soldiers who had been treated in Germany were sent to the U.S. for treatment. Trump has dismissed the injuries as "headaches" but they are very serious.
